title: Grieving MÄori man couldn't make it to his grandma's funeral. So his American coworkers surprised him with haka
text: They also got him a bag of treats from a store in New Zealand and a card before surprising him with the gesture they had prepared for in secret. The coronavirus pandemic may have closed international borders, but it also united people in shared struggles. In 2021, a Maori man named [Jarom Ngakuru (@jaromngakuru)](https://www.tiktok.com/@jaromngakuru), who was working in the U.S., was devastated when he couldnâ€™t attend his grandmotherâ€™s funeral in New Zealand. Seeing his grief, Ngakuru's American co-workers surprised him with a traditional Maori dance that moved him to tears, according to [Good Morning America](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aWmW01cM31g). Ngakuru, heartbroken at not being able to say goodbye to his grandmother, shared with Good Morning America: â€œIt was my nan, my mumâ€™s mum. She passed away. I grew up with her. She is a big influence on my life. She was my last grandparent alive on Earth.â€ He added that in New Zealand when someone passes away, they bury them in the ground â€œreally, really quick.â€ His grandmother was buried within just two days of her passing. â€œBy the time I would be able to fly back home, and make it from America, I was going to miss her funeral,â€ he said. View this post on Instagram He added that he couldnâ€™t fly home even if he tried to, since New Zealand restricted people from flying in and out because of COVID. So, while he was struggling with utter grief, his co-workers came together to help him heal. â€œAnd they just said, â€˜Hey weâ€™re here,â€™â€ Jarom recalled, â€œWe already know whatâ€™s happening. We got together a bunch of things for you.â€ He revealed that his friends got him a bag of treats from a little store in New Zealand, his hometown, along with a card that had a heartwarming message written on it. In addition to all that, they planned a thoughtful gesture by secretly learning the traditional Maori dance called â€œhaka,â€ which is usually performed at significant events like weddings and funerals. The group was led by Jaromâ€™s brother-in-law, Tongan, who also lives in America, and taught them the haka dance in just 24 hours. In May 2024, Jarom uploaded a short [TikTok clip](https://www.tiktok.com/@jaromngakuru/video/7372028383007411464) featuring their performance that brought tears to his eyes back in 2021. "The hardest part about living in America is that we live so far away. I couldn't make it home for my nan's funeral and I was broken! So my boys at work learned the haka without me knowing and brought home to me,â€ he wrote in the caption of the video. The clip shows the group of men passionately performing the traditional dance while vigorously slapping their chests and yelling chants in powerful voices. The tribe Ngapuhi, to which Jarom belongs, has its own style of performing haka, Jarom told Good Morning America. Describing his feelings after watching his coworkers perform the traditional dance, Jarom added, â€œThe emotion I felt was like love and passion.
